title: Stepstowealth
author: Stepstowealth
content: I have a new perspective towards what it means to keep things private. I am thinking that keeping things private does not always mean keeping things to yourself. Before you criticize, I know that to have someone as trusted as that is rare and almost impossible, but they still exist, and sometimes you can find that person in your spouse. If you can share important details like passwords of bank account or safe, or grant them access to important documents, should we not also be able to trust these people with access to our bitcoin wallet?

comments.author: DPHOR
comments.body: Quote from: Stepstowealth on December 06, 2024, 10:44:36 PMI have a new perspective towards what it means to keep things private. I am thinking that keeping things private does not always mean keeping things to yourself. Before you criticize, I know that to have someone as trusted as that is rare and almost impossible, but they still exist, and sometimes you can find that person in your spouse. If you can share important details like passwords of bank account or safe, or grant them access to important documents, should we not also be able to trust these people with access to our bitcoin wallet?Like you made mention; spouse is different from friends or anyone out there. Your family which includes, your wife and children can or may know your bank details which you already outlined but your old school friends can't have such access to you. Therefore, if you are talking about privacy we can talk of your family whom you trust or even if they used it you wouldn't be mad at it than external person or old time friends have their way to it, remember the reaction and action wouldn't be as that of your family.

comments.author: Churchillvv
comments.body: When people talk about security and privacy all I think of is not hiding my private keys, seed phrase from family but rather my online presence or internet activities. I don't know the type of relationship those who say they do not trust their spouse or children have but it's certainly weird to be in a relationship where you don't have trust then why are you there in the first place if you can share such secret with them? anyways we are not talking about relationships but at least it's paramount to have one or two person which should have a clue of what you have and that person could be anyone (family) as long as there is presence of trust

comments.author: BlackBoss_
comments.body: Quote from: Stepstowealth on December 06, 2024, 10:44:36 PMI have a new perspective towards what it means to keep things private. I am thinking that keeping things private does not always mean keeping things to yourself. Privacy is individual privacy or family privacy, and the less information leak, the better for your privacy that can be either individual or family privacy. Private information, after leaked by whatever reasons and to whoever people, will be lost forever. After leaking it, you can not control how it will be spred next and your individual or family privacy leaked forever.QuoteIf you can share important details like passwords of bank account or safe, or grant them access to important documents, should we not also be able to trust these people with access to our bitcoin wallet?If it is about family stuffs, inheritance, you can share sensitive information to people who trust and most important to you, and you want them to inherit your bitcoin in Bitcoin wallets or your fiat in bank accounts.Bitcoin Privacy Resources.

comments.author: Russlenat
comments.body: That bitcoins of yours is considered conjugal property when you acquired within the marriage, meaning your spouse has a right to it. If you truly love your spouse, sharing the private key might be a wise move, you never know what could happen in the future. In case of death, at least your long-held asset can still benefit your family, especially if you’re the breadwinner.You can still maintain the privacy you want because in marriage, the two of you become one. Sharing the private key doesn’t mean losing privacy, it simply means that only the two of you have access to the Bitcoin.

comments.author: Plaguedeath
comments.body: If your spouse can be trusted then it's definitely good.But, @OP, I hope you prepare for yourself if your spouse cheat you or her character changed after she find a better man than you. Since she can access your coins, she know you have a lot money and she can get 50% of wealth you have after divorce.If I want to let someone know of my wealth, it would be my parent, brother, sister or my kids, a big NO for my spouse.

comments.author: icalical
comments.body: Bitcoin wallet secured only with private keys, and anyone who has that has unlimited access, if you have private keys meaning you can do anything with the fund inside the wallet. That's why sharing private key to anyone is risky. However there is option like multisig wallets, which require several confirmations to do transaction. There is also more conservative way like arrange inheritance letter to give your wallet to your trusted person, rather than giving them total control of your fund while you are still alive.

comments.author: Outhue
comments.body: Listen to me carefully. Firstly, we are all humans, meaning we can all fall at the messy of sins.Secondly, money makes humans  changed faster, that trusted fellow can withstand his cool when we are talking about $1000 but he can also be tempted if the worth of your wallet is around $100,000.What kills people faster is money, they betray others because of money, a wise man once told me that to have a long life in this world you need to trust no one, the fact that we are all humans mean the person you trusted the most can betray you. So many powerful men have lost their lives because of the trust they put on someone close to them, and it is always someone close that betrays the most, keep your wallet or Bitcoin to yourself.

comments.author: yhiaali3
comments.body: In my opinion, privacy does not mean hiding your important information from your family, your wife and children. We basically work to secure the needs of the wife and children, so I do not consider them something different and I do not hide my privacy from them.But in some cases when the spouses do not agree or are thinking of separating, then it is wise to maintain your privacy in front of your wife and not reveal your sensitive information.Also, if the children are minors, privacy should be maintained and sensitive data should not be given to them so that they do not misuse it.

comments.author: PrivacyG
comments.body: The shortest answer is NO.  You should not Trust anybody, not even your Spouse.  UNLESS, you acknowledge the risks involved and are ready to risk it all for your love.  It is something many of us are capable of doing and would do once we Trust our Spouses enough.  Particularly if we want to make sure the Funds are going to end up in the right hands if and when we die.HOWEVER.  We as humans are prone to changes.  How many couples have you heard of splitting or divorcing due to one of the partners cheating?  If your Spouse is going to cheat on you a decade from now.  Are you going to Trust the secret you shared with them about accessing your Bitcoin and where the Seed is?  If your Spouse is ready to cheat, they are going to betray you.  This could include copying your Seed to another paper and having that ready in a safe place in the house of the partner they cheated on you with or moving your Bitcoin with out your knowledge.Humans are too volatile for me to Trust any of them.  So, like I said, if you decide you should instruct your partner about moving your Bitcoin then you should also be ready for any risks involved in this decision.

comments.author: Felicity_Tide
comments.body: Quote from: Stepstowealth on December 06, 2024, 10:44:36 PMI have a new perspective towards what it means to keep things private. I am thinking that keeping things private does not always mean keeping things to yourself. Before you criticize, I know that to have someone as trusted as that is rare and almost impossible, but they still exist, and sometimes you can find that person in your spouse. If you can share important details like passwords of bank account or safe, or grant them access to important documents, should we not also be able to trust these people with access to our bitcoin wallet?Interesting question, but I think we have to understand that everyone has their own definition of privacy, but there is definitely one universal definition of privacy, which is how someone control and access their own information at their free will. Now, the reason why I actually feel that everyone has different definition to privacy is because people tend to share sensitive information to trusted parties like the bank related details that you mentioned, but do you know why's that?, It's very simple, the organization behind these banks is what we call central authority (centralization), so it would be easy to meet them up for assistance whenever anything goes wrong.For example, in a case where just you and your partner have the passcode to a bank account, and all of a sudden, you got debited of a massive amount, if your partner eventually denies not spending the money, you can definitely go to the bank to make proper confirmation and ask about the transaction. But with Bitcoin, it's quite the opposite. Your Bitcoin related matters (phrase and private key) should be kept as safe as possible because there is no central authority to consult. Don't even think about the police, because the last time I checked, they don't work for a Bitcoin. Bitcoin does not have an head office. You should know by now that people's Bitcoin gets stolen even under their nose. So, it's not just a good idea. You might feel that a forensic research might help right?, But is it not better to be on a safer side by keeping your details to yourself, rather than becoming a victim at the end of the day.

comments.author: Wexnident
comments.body: Quote from: Stepstowealth on December 06, 2024, 10:44:36 PM~I think it depends on how you'd define private? Personally I'd say it's something you keep solely to yourself. Alone. Regardless of how "close" you are to another person or just in general a group of people, you'd still have some things that are a level above of what you can share with them, and that's generally what private means. Now I wouldn't deny people who want to share their private stuff to others, but in that case it's not that it's not private anymore, just that this "shared" item or concept isn't a top item for you to be kept secret. Simple as that. In this case, it's your Bitcoin wallet.

comments.author: fuguebtc
comments.body: Quote from: Outhue on December 07, 2024, 06:02:38 AMListen to me carefully. Firstly, we are all humans, meaning we can all fall at the messy of sins.Secondly, money makes humans  changed faster, that trusted fellow can withstand his cool when we are talking about $1000 but he can also be tempted if the worth of your wallet is around $100,000.What kills people faster is money, they betray others because of money, a wise man once told me that to have a long life in this world you need to trust no one, the fact that we are all humans mean the person you trusted the most can betray you. So many powerful men have lost their lives because of the trust they put on someone close to them, and it is always someone close that betrays the most, keep your wallet or Bitcoin to yourself. Not everyone betrays each other for money, just because one man was betrayed by another and told you, doesn't mean the rest will be just as bad. Furthermore, if you can't trust anyone, not even your wife or mother, then don't expect anyone to trust you, and basically, you're not someone worth trusting either . A person who never trusts anyone does not deserve any trust in return.Honestly, money is very important and the most important thing in society because without money, my family and I would not be able to survive in this world. But between family, husband and wife, children...I will choose them because if I lose them I will never find them again. For bitcoin, money...they are all physical and they always exist in this world and it is not too difficult to get them back if I lose them .

comments.author: retreat
comments.body: Quote from: Stepstowealth on December 06, 2024, 10:44:36 PM-snip-should we not also be able to trust these people with access to our bitcoin wallet?It's up to the person to give access to their Bitcoin wallet to who they trust, whether it's their wife, child, or closest friend. But there are individuals who prefer to keep it to themselves, not a matter of individualism or what, but he feels that money can cause relationships to be strained, for example he gave access to the wallet to his wife, but his wife said that he should sell the Bitcoin when he found out its value, but he was adamant about holding it, and without him knowing his wife sold it at a later date. This is one of the many risks of entrusting the private keys of one's Bitcoin wallet to others, and therefore one should be more careful with their private keys and not entrust them to others.

comments.author: Charles-Tim
comments.body: Quote from: Stepstowealth on December 06, 2024, 10:44:36 PMIf you can share important details like passwords of bank account or safe, or grant them access to important documents, should we not also be able to trust these people with access to our bitcoin wallet?There are some things I see as stupid. It may not be stupid to you and some other people. If nothing happens to me, my spouse and children can not be able to access my coins. But I would have taught them and let them know how they can access bitcoin wallets and exchanges. And I may even be sending them some money in coins for them to exchange it to fiat themselves. If your spouse want to do something stupid about your property that you bought with your name, you can easily recover those back but when it comes to bitcoin which nobody knows the owner, the recovery will be difficult or impossible.

comments.author: CageMabok
comments.body: Quote from: Stepstowealth on December 06, 2024, 10:44:36 PMI have a new perspective towards what it means to keep things private. I am thinking that keeping things private does not always mean keeping things to yourself. Before you criticize, I know that to have someone as trusted as that is rare and almost impossible, but they still exist, and sometimes you can find that person in your spouse. If you can share important details like passwords of bank account or safe, or grant them access to important documents, should we not also be able to trust these people with access to our bitcoin wallet?What you said is not entirely wrong, but the problem is when we see many divorces that occur when some of them have been married for several years and finally have to separate very sadly even though they already have children. So I can't completely agree with that even though it is very possible for some people if they can be sure that their life partner will never run away from them again until the end of their lives.But if that is still not certain because of the estrangement of the husband and wife relationship due to something or due to differences of opinion, of course there is no need to share everything with our life partner even though he or she is the person who is always in our house at this time. And actually I would rather share this with my child when my child is old enough to know everything and I would direct him not to give it to anyone including his own mother if that is possible for him.

comments.author: Sim_card
comments.body: Privacy does not mean that you keep secrets from your family because your wife is the first person you should trust and share yout secrets with. The same goes to your kids because family members are not strangers but part of you. Trust and love should be built in the family so that we can trust each other with out lives. Your bitcoin is safe with whoever you trust in your family.

comments.author: lovesmayfamilis
comments.body: I won't even read what others will say, because I expect many to assure you that in this life you should trust only yourself. But someone who has been together with their spouse for a long time will certainly not agree with such statements, because people who have lived together for many years (in a good sense) should have common property, from real estate to finances. Perhaps this is too utopian a statement, but to the surprise, and perhaps envy, of some, it exists. And this example applies to my life. And yes, what I have, my spouse knows and has, which can be said in the opposite direction.

comments.author: m2017
comments.body: Quote from: Stepstowealth on December 06, 2024, 10:44:36 PMI have a new perspective towards what it means to keep things private. I am thinking that keeping things private does not always mean keeping things to yourself. Before you criticize, I know that to have someone as trusted as that is rare and almost impossible, but they still exist, and sometimes you can find that person in your spouse. If you can share important details like passwords of bank account or safe, or grant them access to important documents, should we not also be able to trust these people with access to our bitcoin wallet?Your offer to trust access to bitcoin wallet works only if these people can really be trusted. Otherwise, you are only creating a very strong threat to the contents of your "wallet", be it a bank account or a crypto wallet.As one literary detective character said, spouses are the 1st suspects in a crime. Look at the divorce statistics. Are you really ready to trust your money to those who are ready to bite your throat after a couple of years of living together?Everything is good when it is done well. If your spouse can be trusted (deservedly entrust) with your crypto wallet, then this is wonderful and even correct, from the point of view of risk diversification (if an accident happens to you).

comments.author: Synchronice
comments.body: Quote from: Stepstowealth on December 06, 2024, 10:44:36 PMI have a new perspective towards what it means to keep things private. I am thinking that keeping things private does not always mean keeping things to yourself. Before you criticize, I know that to have someone as trusted as that is rare and almost impossible, but they still exist, and sometimes you can find that person in your spouse. If you can share important details like passwords of bank account or safe, or grant them access to important documents, should we not also be able to trust these people with access to our bitcoin wallet?If you share important details like the password of bank account and something happens, there is still a chance to get your money back. If someone steals money from your safe, you also might get it back but with Bitcoin, if someone steals it, there is a very low chance to get them back because there is no way to stop the Bitcoin transaction and if the thief doesn't tell you keys, no one will be able to get access to the wallet but this depends on the person.Anyways, I'm against trusting someone when it comes to sensitive information like that. Yes, family members might be loyal to you to the death but you can't be 100% sure. There are many cases when things went wrong between family members. I think you can trust your mother and father more than wife or kids. I know many of you might tell me that this is the other way but today, men have less rights and wives don't care about divorce. Kids are kids and they aren't reliable.
